name: 鄭以旋
objective: This course teaches relevant and up-to-date business topics such as finance, globalization, start-ups, marketing, logistics, risk management and business ethics (e.g. fair trade). We will also read foundational literature on economics to familiarize students with basic concepts in commerce and business. Lastly, students will be taught practical business English skills in writing and speaking.
schedule:
Schedule:

Week 1 – Introduction 
Week 5 – Holiday
Week 9 – No class
Week 10 - Mid-term
Week 16 – Final Exam
Week 17 - Holiday
Week 18 – School exam week (no class)

Weeks 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15:
1.　　Work on a selected unit from the textbook. 
2.　　Read and discuss one current business news article or issue.
3.　　Group presentation (schedule to be determined).
scorePolicy:
Attendance policy:
Seven or more absences from Week 3 onwards will result in a grade of 0% for the course.   

Assessment:
Mid-term* 　　　　　　　　　　25%
Final exam* 　　　　　　　　　　35%
Group presentation　　　　　　　　30%
Attendance and participation　　　　10%　　　　

* At the lecturer’s sole discretion, a make-up mid-term or exam may be granted upon presentation of a proof of leave approval from the university system within 10 days of the date of the mid-term or exam.

Textbook: Intelligent Business Advanced Coursebook (Pearson)
materials:
Textbook; Intelligent Business Coursebook, Advanced

Readings for group presentations:

1.　　Thomas Piketty, “Introduction” and “Toward a Democratic, Ecological and Multicultural Socialism,” A Brief History of Inequality, 2022.
2.　　Michael Sandel, “Introduction” and “Chapter 1: Jumping the Queue,” What Money Can't Buy: The Moral Limits of Markets, 2012.
3.　　Thomas Piketty, “Introduction,” Capital in the Twenty-first Century, 2013.
4.　　Nick Srnicek, “Chapter 2: Platform Capitalism,” Platform Capitalism, 2016.
5.　　Nick Srnicek, “Chapter 3: Great Platform Wars,” Platform Capitalism, 2016.
6.　　Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner, “Introduction” and “Chapter 5: What Makes a Perfect Parent,” Freakonomics, 2005.
7.　　Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, “Chapter 1: MEGA Make Economics Great Again,” Good Economics for Hard Times, 2019” and “Chapter 3: THe Pains from Trade.”
